G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord or person acting on the landlord’s behalf is liable if he “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and was responsible for maintaining the Premises and building in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and other applicable laws.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and was responsible for maintaining the Premises and building in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and other applicable laws.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 6.proposition: This action is brought in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3 and 6, which confer jurisdiction over actions and proceedings concerning residential tenancies, violations of the State Sanitary Code, and claims under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 3, 4.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court because the Premises are located in Dorchester, a neighborhood of Boston, Suffolk County, Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 185C, §§ 1, 3, 4.

105 CMR 410.000 (the State Sanitary Code.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000 (the State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 CMR 410.000 (the State Sanitary Code.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant retained control over the heating system and was responsible for supplying and maintaining heat to the Premises in accordance with state and local law, including 105 CMR 410.000 (the State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation).

105 CMR 410.201 and 410.201(A)(1).proposition: Massachusetts law, including 105 CMR 410.201 and 410.201(A)(1), requires that the landlord provide and maintain a heating system capable of maintaining a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F between 11:01 p.m. and 6:59 a.m. during the heating season.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts. See, e.g., Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes an implied covenant/warranty of quiet enjoyment in these residential leases and applies it, but it does not state that such a covenant is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts as a general rule. The court assumes the existence of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in the leases before it and focuses on whether the landlords’ conduct breached that covenant; it does not articulate the broader, categorical proposition about all residential tenancies. Thus, the case is consistent with but does not itself clearly establish the universal rule stated in the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge. Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts. See, e.g., Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that “every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant” of quiet enjoyment, and it discusses that covenant specifically in the residential landlord‑tenant context and in connection with G.L. c. 186, § 14. In doing so, it confirms that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law in Massachusetts tenancies, including residential ones, thus supporting the proposition for which it is cited.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy…. Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Id. Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282–283 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: A substantial and persistent failure to provide essential services, including heat, in violation of the State Sanitary Code constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282–283 (1994) (defining interference with quiet enjoyment as acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises); Jiannaras v. Alfant, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 848 (1983) (unreported) (lack of adequate heat can support quiet enjoyment claims).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does define interference with quiet enjoyment as acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold and finds that serious loss of use of common areas due to drug activity can constitute such interference. However, the opinion does not address failures to provide essential services like heat, nor does it involve or mention violations of the State Sanitary Code as the basis for quiet enjoyment liability. Thus it supports only the definitional portion of the proposition, not the specific claim that substantial, persistent breaches of essential services/Sanitary Code (such as lack of heat) constitute interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Jiannaras v. Alfant, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 8.raw_text: Jiannaras v. Alfant, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 848 (1983) (unreported)
Jiannaras v. Alfant, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: A substantial and persistent failure to provide essential services, including heat, in violation of the State Sanitary Code constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282–283 (1994) (defining interference with quiet enjoyment as acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises); Jiannaras v. Alfant, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 848 (1983) (unreported) (lack of adequate heat can support quiet enjoyment claims).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–203 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The Housing Court and appellate courts have recognized that violations of the State Sanitary Code, including failure to maintain minimum heat levels, may support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–203 (1979); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–777 (1994); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: This opinion deals with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the tenant’s right to rent abatement for lack of heat and hot water constituting substantial State Sanitary Code violations. It does not analyze or apply G.L. c. 186, §14 or the doctrine of breach of quiet enjoyment, nor does it characterize the Sanitary Code violations as supporting a quiet enjoyment claim. Thus, while it clearly ties heat-related Code violations to habitability, it does not provide authority for a breach of quiet enjoyment theory.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for… The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969)… The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–777 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: The Housing Court and appellate courts have recognized that violations of the State Sanitary Code, including failure to maintain minimum heat levels, may support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–203 (1979); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–777 (1994); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses serious habitability problems, including lack of heat, but the appellate issue and holding concern only the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a Section 8 tenancy. While the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the SJC expressly notes that no damages were awarded on that claim and does not analyze or affirm any legal rule tying State Sanitary Code violations or failure to maintain heat to liability for breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition cited.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The Housing Court and appellate courts have recognized that violations of the State Sanitary Code, including failure to maintain minimum heat levels, may support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–203 (1979); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–777 (1994); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion is focused on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent obligations, not on breach of quiet enjoyment. The excerpt does not discuss G.L. c. 186, §14 or the doctrine of quiet enjoyment, nor does it link sanitary code violations (such as lack of heat) to that specific cause of action. While it recognizes that code violations can affect rent liability and habitability, it does not provide authority for the separate proposition that such violations support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide adequate heat, in the circumstances alleged, rises to at least a “negligent or careless” interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, for which statutory damages are available. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–852 (1997); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–763 (1979).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and makes clear that liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord, not strict liability. In doing so, it expressly cites Darmetko (a failure-to-repair case involving habitability) as an example of a landlord’s negligent omission violating § 14. While Al‑Ziab is a lead-paint case, its holding is a general statement about § 14’s fault standard that applies equally to a failure to provide adequate heat, supporting the proposition that such conduct, if negligent or careless, can give rise to statutory quiet enjoyment damages.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt:
Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

…we noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz… citing… Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof)….

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–763 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide adequate heat, in the circumstances alleged, rises to at least a “negligent or careless” interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, for which statutory damages are available. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–852 (1997); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–763 (1979).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that the landlord’s failure to repair a leaking roof constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and allows statutory damages and attorney’s fees on that basis. However, the court does not address the degree of fault required (e.g., “negligent or careless”) to establish liability under § 14, nor does it include any discussion of inadequate heat; the case concerns defective floors and a leaky roof. Thus, while Darmetko supports that certain repair failures can violate § 14 and trigger statutory damages, it does not specifically support the proposition about negligent failure to provide heat.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises… Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all ‘actual and consequential damages’ where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Plaintiff further invokes related statutory and common-law protections establishing the standards of conduct for landlords, including, without limitation: a. G.L. c. 239, § 8A (allowing tenants to assert breaches of warranty, habitability, and quiet enjoyment as defenses and counterclaims in eviction proceedings); b. G.L. c. 93A, § 2 (unfair and deceptive acts or practices in trade or commerce), and the standards articulated in 940 CMR 3.17 regarding landlord‑tenant practices, as interpretive of landlords’ obligations (cited here as background and not as a separate claim); c. The implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and its progeny, to the extent such standards inform the scope of the landlord’s duties owed to Plaintiff (cited here as background and not as a separate claim).

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2.proposition: Plaintiff further invokes related statutory and common-law protections establishing the standards of conduct for landlords, including, without limitation: a. G.L. c. 239, § 8A (allowing tenants to assert breaches of warranty, habitability, and quiet enjoyment as defenses and counterclaims in eviction proceedings); b. G.L. c. 93A, § 2 (unfair and deceptive acts or practices in trade or commerce), and the standards articulated in 940 CMR 3.17 regarding landlord‑tenant practices, as interpretive of landlords’ obligations (cited here as background and not as a separate claim); c. The implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and its progeny, to the extent such standards inform the scope of the landlord’s duties owed to Plaintiff (cited here as background and not as a separate claim).

940 CMR 3.17.proposition: Plaintiff further invokes related statutory and common-law protections establishing the standards of conduct for landlords, including, without limitation: a. G.L. c. 239, § 8A (allowing tenants to assert breaches of warranty, habitability, and quiet enjoyment as defenses and counterclaims in eviction proceedings); b. G.L. c. 93A, § 2 (unfair and deceptive acts or practices in trade or commerce), and the standards articulated in 940 CMR 3.17 regarding landlord‑tenant practices, as interpretive of landlords’ obligations (cited here as background and not as a separate claim); c. The implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and its progeny, to the extent such standards inform the scope of the landlord’s duties owed to Plaintiff (cited here as background and not as a separate claim).
